Compared with commercial antistatic PVC films containing CB and anti-static agents, the MLG/PVC composites exhibit some advantages of higher electrical conductivity, lower conductive-filler loadings, and especially much better stability to change in environmental humidity due to high intrinsic conductivity of MLG, large lateral size and high aspect ratio of the used MLG.

On one hand, as mentioned above, there is a lack of strong interfacial bonding in the MLG/PVC composite due to the less functional groups existing on the MLG surfaces, and consequently the presence of MLG cannot greatly improve the thermal stability of the MLG/PVC composites.
Therefore, in our work, the low thermal stability of the MLG/PVC composites is mainly attributed to the weak interactions and good compatibility between the MLG and PVC.

On the other hand, The presence of MLG can greatly improve tensile modulus and glass transition temperature of the MLG/PVC composites, but decreasing tensile strength and thermal stability of the MLG/PVC composites, which is closely associated with crumpled morphology of the MLG, weak MLG-PVC interactions, and high DOP-adsorption onto MLG surfaces.
